speaker: LUCIUS
text: Who, the Lord Timon? He is my very good

speaker: LUCIUS
text: friend and an honorable gentleman.

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text: We know him for no less, though we

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text: are but strangers to him. But I can tell you one

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text: thing, my lord, and which I hear from common

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text: rumors: now Lord Timon’s happy hours are done

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text: and past, and his estate shrinks from him.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Fie, no, do not believe it. He cannot want for

speaker: LUCIUS
text: money.

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text: But believe you this, my lord, that

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text: not long ago one of his men was with the Lord

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text: Lucullus to borrow fifty talents, nay, urged

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text: extremely for ’t, and showed what necessity

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text: belonged to ’t, and yet was denied.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: How?

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text: I tell you, denied, my lord.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: What a strange case was that! Now, before the

speaker: LUCIUS
text: gods, I am ashamed on ’t. Denied that honorable

speaker: LUCIUS
text: man? There was very little honor showed in ’t. For

speaker: LUCIUS
text: my own part, I must needs confess I have received

speaker: LUCIUS
text: some small kindnesses from him, as money, plate,

speaker: LUCIUS
text: jewels, and suchlike trifles, nothing comparing to

speaker: LUCIUS
text: his; yet had he mistook him and sent to me, I

speaker: LUCIUS
text: should ne’er have denied his occasion fifty talents.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: See, by good hap, yonder’s my lord.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text:
I have sweat to see his Honor.
                 
                To
                 
                Lucius
                .
               My

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: honored lord.

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Servilius. You are kindly met, sir. Fare thee

speaker: LUCIUS
text: well. Commend me to thy honorable virtuous lord,

speaker: LUCIUS
text: my very exquisite friend.

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: May it please your Honor, my lord hath

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: sent—

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Ha! What has he sent? I am so much endeared

speaker: LUCIUS
text: to that lord; he’s ever sending. How shall I thank

speaker: LUCIUS
text: him, think’st thou? And what has he sent now?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: Has only sent his present occasion now, my

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: lord, requesting your Lordship to supply his

speaker: SERVILIUS
text: instant use with fifty talents.

speaker: LUCIUS
text:
I
               
              know
               
              his
               
              Lordship
               
              is
               
              but
               
              merry
               
              with
               
              me
              .

speaker: LUCIUS
text:
He
               
              cannot
               
              want
               
              fifty-five
               
              hundred
               
              talents
              .

speaker: SERVILIUS
text:
But
               
              in
               
              the
               
              meantime
               
              he
               
              wants
               
              less
              ,
               
              my
               
              lord
              .

speaker: SERVILIUS
text:
If
               
              his
               
              occasion
               
              were
               
              not
               
              virtuous
              ,

speaker: SERVILIUS
text:
I
               
              should
               
              not
               
              urge
               
              it
               
              half
               
              so
               
              faithfully
              .

speaker: LUCIUS
text:
Dost
               
              thou
               
              speak
               
              seriously
              ,
               
              Servilius
              ?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text:
Upon
               
              my
               
              soul
              ,
               
              ’tis
               
              true
              ,
               
              sir
              .

speaker: LUCIUS
text: What a wicked beast was I to disfurnish

speaker: LUCIUS
text: myself against such a good time, when I might ha’

speaker: LUCIUS
text: shown myself honorable! How unluckily it happened

speaker: LUCIUS
text: that I should purchase the day before for a

speaker: LUCIUS
text: little part, and undo a great deal of honor! Servilius,

speaker: LUCIUS
text: now before the gods, I am not able to do—the

speaker: LUCIUS
text: more beast, I say!—I was sending to use Lord

speaker: LUCIUS
text: Timon myself, these gentlemen can witness; but I

speaker: LUCIUS
text: would not for the wealth of Athens I had done ’t

speaker: LUCIUS
text: now. Commend me bountifully to his good Lordship,

speaker: LUCIUS
text: and I hope his Honor will conceive the fairest

speaker: LUCIUS
text: of me, because I have no power to be kind. And tell

speaker: LUCIUS
text: him this from me: I count it one of my greatest

speaker: LUCIUS
text: afflictions, say, that I cannot pleasure such an honorable

speaker: LUCIUS
text: gentleman. Good Servilius, will you

speaker: LUCIUS
text: befriend me so far as to use mine own words to

speaker: LUCIUS
text: him?

speaker: SERVILIUS
text:
Yes
              ,
               
              sir
              ,
               
              I
               
              shall
              .

speaker: LUCIUS
text: I’ll look you out a good turn, Servilius.

speaker: LUCIUS
text:
True
              ,
               
              as
               
              you
               
              said
              ,
               
              Timon
               
              is
               
              shrunk
               
              indeed
              ,

speaker: LUCIUS
text:
And
               
              he
               
              that’s
               
              once
               
              denied
               
              will
               
              hardly
               
              speed
              .

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Do
               
              you
               
              observe
               
              this
              ,
               
              Hostilius
              ?

speaker:
SECOND
               
              STRANGER
text:
Ay
              ,
               
              too
               
              well
              .

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Why
              ,
               
              this
               
              is
               
              the
               
              world’s
               
              soul
              ,
               
              and
               
              just
               
              of
               
              the
               
              same
               
              piece

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Is
               
              every
               
              flatterer’s
               
              sport
              .
               
              Who
               
              can
               
              call
               
              him
               
              his
               
              friend

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
That
               
              dips
               
              in
               
              the
               
              same
               
              dish
              ?
               
              For
              ,
               
              in
               
              my
               
              knowing
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Timon
               
              has
               
              been
               
              this
               
              lord’s
               
              father

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
And
               
              kept
               
              his
               
              credit
               
              with
               
              his
               
              purse
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Supported
               
              his
               
              estate
              ,
               
              nay
              ,
               
              Timon’s
               
              money

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Has
               
              paid
               
              his
               
              men
               
              their
               
              wages
              .
               
              He
               
              ne’er
               
              drinks

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
But
               
              Timon’s
               
              silver
               
              treads
               
              upon
               
              his
               
              lip
              .

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
And
               
              yet
              —
              O
              ,
               
              see
               
              the
               
              monstrousness
               
              of
               
              man

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
When
               
              he
               
              looks
               
              out
               
              in
               
              an
               
              ungrateful
               
              shape
              !
              —

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
He
               
              does
               
              deny
               
              him
              ,
               
              in
               
              respect
               
              of
               
              his
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
What
               
              charitable
               
              men
               
              afford
               
              to
               
              beggars
              .

speaker:
THIRD
               
              STRANGER
text:
Religion
               
              groans
               
              at
               
              it
              .

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
For
               
              mine
               
              own
               
              part
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
I
               
              never
               
              tasted
               
              Timon
               
              in
               
              my
               
              life
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Nor
               
              came
               
              any
               
              of
               
              his
               
              bounties
               
              over
               
              me

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
To
               
              mark
               
              me
               
              for
               
              his
               
              friend
              .
               
              Yet
               
              I
               
              protest
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
For
               
              his
               
              right
               
              noble
               
              mind
              ,
               
              illustrious
               
              virtue
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
And
               
              honorable
               
              carriage
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Had
               
              his
               
              necessity
               
              made
               
              use
               
              of
               
              me
              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
I
               
              would
               
              have
               
              put
               
              my
               
              wealth
               
              into

              ,

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
And
               
              the

              should
               
              have

              to
               
              him
              ,

speaker:
FIRST

text:
So
               
              much
               
              I

              his
               
              heart
              .
               
              But
               
              I

speaker:
FIRST
               
              STRANGER
text:
Men

              with

For
